title: What does it mean by General Power of Attorney (with Durable Provision) in Section (G) ?
question: In (G) it refers to Gifts to Charities and individuals other than Attorney-in-Fact/Agent. Since he assigned a person who is his boyfriend/partner as his Power of Attorney which I am concerned about. Can a Power of Attorney use this person's money to pay off his own small debts meaning credit cards, pay for a storage unit, gas for his vehicle and everyday necessities? What are the limits for a Power of Attorney to purchase things? I just want to make sure this person isn't going to screw him over like others have done in the past. Will he have problems or considered he is breaking the law on anything I mentioned?
answers: A General Power of Attorney is a document that creates many significant legal powers and allows the person who is the attorney in fact to essentially stand in the shoes of the person who gave the power. A Power of Attorney is only valid so long as the person who gave the power has the mental capacity to contract and handle financial affairs unless it is a durable power of attorney. A durable power of attorney is valid despite the loss of mental capacity by the principal. The attorney in fact is a fiduciary and held to the highest standard of care in dealing with the principal's finances. They cannot use the money for their own benefit, but may be able to be compensated for their services if the POA provides for compensation. Also an attorney in fact is entitled to be reimbursed for their out of pocket expenses directly related to providing services to the principal.

"DURABLE"means that the authority granted ENDURES a later lack of capacity. Otherwise the authority granted terminates when the Principal loses capacity, so that a protective proceeding Conservatorship in Calif, Guatdianship in other states) is necessary for a Fiduciary to manage the Principal's affairs.

The SELF-DEALING issue is different:is the Attorney-In-Fact/Agent authirized in the POA document to "Self-Deal"? I cannit tell from your post to whom the POA authorizes gifts to be made by the Agent: to third party charities? To the Agent?
Please show the document to an estate-planning Attorney with elder law knowledge & experience for appropriate next steps, based on its contents and your facts.

The agent must act in the interest of the principal - even if doing so is not in the agent's best interest. Self dealing is strictly prohibited. I agree that fighting this is going to be expensive. Your local poice or sheriff may be able to investigate - especially if the "victim (principal) is elderly.

The holder of a POA may not self deal. Period.
However, the remedy is not so easily pursued.

The Power of Attorney (POA) typically states the extent and limitations (if any) of the powers. A "durable" provision simply means that the POA still will be effective after the incapacity (unconsciousness, etc.) of the principal (the person who signed the POA).
